thread.title: San Jose State coach Ron Caragher encouraged despite loss to Auburn
thread.title_full: San Jose State coach Ron Caragher encouraged despite loss to Auburn

author:
Jon Wilner

jwilner@mercurynews.com
title: San Jose State coach Ron Caragher encouraged despite loss to Auburn
text:
Posted: 10/05/2015 03:08:19 PM PDT Updated: 10/05/2015 03:08:22 PM PDT SAN JOSE -- After a game in SEC country, a refueling stop in Oklahoma City that featured gas gushing from a leak on the airplane, a dead-of-night return to campus and hours of video review, San Jose State coach Ron Caragher pronounced himself "very encouraged" by the two-touchdown loss at Auburn. 
"There's a lot to build on,'' Caragher said Monday. "I think the team answered another call." 
The Spartans (2-3) aren't close to a finished product, but one issue requires attention above all as Mountain West play resumes this week with a trip to UNLV. 
San Jose State ranks 125th in the nation (out of 127 teams) in kickoff coverage, with opponents averaging 29.6 yards per return. 
Auburn bettered that average by almost 10 yards. Combine their success on returns with four SJSU turnovers, and the Tigers' average starting field position was their 47 yard line -- essentially midfield. 
"It continues to be addressed,'' Caragher said. "We haven't cleaned that up like I thought we would. I like the scheme. There's a point where the players have to shed the defenders and make tackles.'' 
So bad was the kickoff coverage that it played a role in Caragher's decision to attempt an on-side kick with five minutes left and SJSU down by seven. 
Once Auburn realized the on-side kick was coming, it called timeout to get proper personnel on the field. Despite losing the element of surprise, the Spartans went ahead with their plan. Advertisement 
Auburn recovered at the Spartans' 45 and scored the game-sealing touchdown two plays later. 
"I don't have any qualms with it,'' Caragher said. "We were playing to get the ball back to tie the game." 
Linebacker Christian Tago suffered what Caragher described as a stinger and is questionable this week, but there were no major injuries. 
"Those games can have a devastating effect on the rest of the season, but we held up well,'' Caragher said. 
Tailback Thomas Tucker, the primary backup to workhorse Tyler Ervin, will be "down for a little while" with an ankle injury suffered weeks ago, Caragher said. 
Starting quarterback Kenny Potter (ankle), who missed the past two games, continues to recover. Caragher declined to project whether Potter will play Saturday. 
The Spartans' Oct. 17 Homecoming game against San Diego State will start at 7:30 and be televised by ESPNU. For more on college sports, see Jon Wilner's College Hotline at blogs.mercurynews.com/collegesports . Contact him at jwilner@mercurynews.com or 408-920-5716.
